ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: A numerical study of residual stress induced in machined silicon surfaces by molecular dynamics simulation

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Residual stresses in machined surface are regarded as a critical factor affecting the quality and service life of components. However, little research has been conducted to reveal the formation of residual stresses as well as the relation between machining conditions and residual stresses at the nanometric scale. In this study, residual stresses in machined surfaces of monocrystalline silicon are computed based on molecular dynamics simulation. An orthogonal machining configuration is adopted, and diamond cutting tools are used. The numerical approach developed is able to reveal stress evolution during and after machining, as well as in-depth residual stress distributions. The results indicate that the material stresses are stabilized within a manageable amount of computation time, and the in-depth normal stress along the tool moving direction has a more dynamical and significant pattern compared with other stress components. Meanwhile, the effects of depth of cut and tool rake angle are investigated. It is found that the increase of depth of cut results in the decrease of maximum tensile residual stress on the machined surfaces and the increase of maximum compressive residual stress underneath the surface. Similar observations are observed when the tool rake angle changes from positive to negative. It is believed that the more negative tool rake angles or the larger depths of cut induce a more drastic phase transformation to the machined surfaces, and this makes the in-depth residual stress distributions more compressive.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: It is well known that residual stresses distributed in machined surfaces are complicated due to the complex nature of machining processes—various intriguing challenges are rooted in the fundamental manufacturing process, such as the extremely high strain rate. Residual stress distribution could significantly affect the quality of machined components produced by the traditional and micro/nanoscale processes. In particular, residual stress is vital for the component’s surface properties and performances, including surface hardness, fatigue life, corrosion resistance, and the overall component’s strength. Machined components with significant tensile stresses are more vulnerable to fatigue cracking and corrosion, while compressive residual stresses are regarded as beneficial in that they help prevent the initiation of cracks, decrease the crack rates, and thus enhance the component’s durability and structural integrity [1, 2].

A number of studies have investigated the surface residual stresses generated by machining processes at macro- and mesoscales. These studies adopt either experimental or numerical approaches to investigate the formation mechanism of residual stress, the effect of machining parameters, or the sensitivity of model parameter selection. However, they cannot be used to investigate the residual stresses generated in nanomachining. This is because those experimental approaches developed are not capable of measuring the residual stresses at the nanometric scale. Also, those numerical approaches such as finite-element analysis at macro- or mesoscales are difficult to be extended to the nanometric scale because the fundamental governing equations may no longer be valid. What is more, those numerical approaches rely too much on the selection of proper material models and the model parameters.

On the other hand, molecular dynamics (MD) simulation is an effective approach for studying many manufacturing processes at smaller scales. It can help reveal various phenomena that are out of reach for the traditional approaches. The most prominent benefit of using MD simulation is that without relying on many pre-assumed material models, it is capable of capturing the evolution of position, velocity, stresses, and energy information of each atom or particle. For machining research, many researchers have adopted MD simulation to study a number of issues which used to be very challenging for the traditional numerical simulation or experimental approaches. Despite numerous studies of MD simulation of nanomachining, there is a lack of study in the existing literature regarding residual stress generation and distribution [3]. As such, this study aims to bridge the research gap by developing an MD simulation based approach for the investigation of residual stresses in machined surfaces. Single-crystal silicon is chosen as the work material in that it is one of the most important materials for numerous semiconductor devices and other applications such as solar panels.

The remainder of the paper is arranged as follows. In the next section, we provide a brief literature review of relevant studies. Then, the construction of the MD simulation model is introduced and the machining conditions described. Thereafter, simulation results are obtained for all the cases. The cutting force evolution, chip formation, and the residual stress distributions are summarized. The effects of tool rake angle and depth cut are also revealed. Conclusions are drawn in the final section.

Section1.Heading: Brief literature review
Section1.Para: Below we survey the necessary literature related to this study. The survey mainly covers three aspects, namely, residual stress generation in macro- or mesomachining of silicon, general MD simulation of machining, and special structural alteration of silicon material in machining.

In the literature, the studies of residual stress in silicon or other brittle materials in machining and grinding processes are actually fewer than those of metal machining. Early in 1992, Sparks and Paesler [4] obtained the residual stress profiles in machined germanium using micro-Raman spectroscopy. The machined germanium is characterized as a surface layer under compression, a compressive-to-tensile transition in a deeper-lying region, and finally relaxation in the unstressed bulk material. Shibata et al. [5] studied ductile-regime turning of single-crystal silicon along different crystallographic directions in (001) and (111) planes. It was found that the machinability depends on the crystal surface and cutting directions, and the critical regime of ductile–brittle transitions can be proposed based on the defined slip orientation factor. Meanwhile, Lucazeau and Abello [6] adopted micro-Raman spectroscopy to investigate the residual stress field induced by micro-indentation by mapping the indented zones. It was found that amorphous silicon exists in the center of indentation and the amorphous silicon is partly recrystallized. Others also used micro-Raman spectroscopy to study the phase transition and residual stress in crystalline silicon induced by machining and grinding [7–9]. Yan et al. [7] confirmed that the existence of near-surface amorphous layers is introduced by machining and the Raman shift is strongly affected by structural changes and residual strains. Zhang et al. [8] also used this technique to verify that the ground silicon surface presents compressive residual stress. The rough ground wafer has the lowest stress value since the material is removed in brittle mode while the semi-fine ground surface has the largest stress value because of more phase transformation. Similarly, residual stress in diamond-turned single-silicon crystal was measured by Jasinevicius et al. [9]. The study revealed the relationship between surface residual stress and a series of turning parameters, including feed rate and depth of cut. Besides, some modeling approaches have been developed to study residual stresses in machining of silicon or other brittle materials. For instance, the modeling of ductile-mode material removal in rotary ultrasonic machining was performed by Pei and Ferreira [10]. This model helped identify the influence of some process parameters on the material removal rate in ductile regime. Tian et al. [11] developed a two-dimensional axisymmetric finite element model to predict the full-field residual stress in ground silicon wafers. The effects of initial strain, thickness of bulk silicon layer, and thickness of damage layer on the maximum residual stress were addressed. In addition, to achieve minimum surface damage and smooth surface roughness in silicon machining, Young et al. [12] proposed a novel method to predict the critical depth of cut.

In the area of MD simulation of machining, Inamura and colleagues were among the first to use this approach to reveal the stress-and-strain distribution in machining at the nanometric scale [13, 14], in which little shear stress concentration was found in the primary shear zone of machining. Inspired by the potential demonstrated in the pioneering studies, other researchers have carried out numerous studies since then. One concentration is on the friction phenomena in nanometric machining. Maekawa and Itoh [15] applied the MD simulation approach to investigate friction and tool wear in nanomachining. The Morse potential and various cohesion energy formulations were utilized to analyze the overall friction between cutting tool and work material. Fang and Weng [16] observed the stick–slip phenomenon in the MD simulation of copper machining by a conical diamond tool. Ji et al. [17] developed a unique MD simulation approach along tool/chip interface for friction in machining from a new perspective. The entire friction stress distributions along the tool rake face can be obtained. It was discovered that the friction models developed for traditional machining are not applicable for nanomachining. In fact, a more intensive area of study was about the effect of machining parameters in nanomachining. Komanduri et al. [18] discovered that the cutting force components along the cutting direction and the specific energy can be significantly affected by tool rake angle in nanomachining. Lin and Huang employed an MDFM (molecular dynamics with finite element deformation model) [19] to demonstrate that the cutting speed might a significant influence on the distribution of strain and stress in the shear zone. Similarly, Pei et al. [20] indicated that smaller depths of cut would result in smoother machined surfaces due to less plastic deformation and fewer dislocations. Komanduri et al. [21] also concluded that material deformation, dislocation movement, and cutting force are greatly affected by crystal orientation and cutting direction. Shi et al. [22] developed the first real three-dimensional MD simulation model for multi-pass machining, in which surface creation is realized by machining adjacent grooves with tool feed. In addition, some strong research interests have emerged on improving the computational efficiency of MD simulation of machining. Hybrid molecular finite element analysis (FEA) was adopted to predict the cutting forces of a silicon wafer in micromachining [23]. It turned out to be effective for FEA to adopt the material properties such as yield stress, ultimate stress, and modulus of elasticity obtained by the MD model. Similarly, Sun et al. [24] and Shiari et al. [25] developed their own MD-FEA approaches respectively for multi-scale simulation of nanomachining, in which the MD model is used for atomistic description near the interface while the continuum model is adopted for the bulk material.

Moreover, it is well recognized that in a machining process, the high hydrostatic pressure can trigger phase transformation in some brittle materials, such as silicon and germanium. The phase transformation makes machining brittle silicon in ductile mode possible. MD simulation has been used to investigate the phase transformation of silicon on many occasions. By using MD simulation, Fang et al. [26] discovered that silicon chips have amorphous structure in ductile-mode cutting and polycrystalline structure in brittle-mode cutting. Cai et al. [27] conducted MD simulation to model the ductile cutting of monocrystalline silicon. In the study, with the increase of the tool edge radius, the decrease of shear stress around the cutting edge was observed and the chip can no longer be formed in ductile mode. In another study [28], the same group of researchers confirmed the existence of ‘dynamic hard particles’ in the chip formation zone, as a result of monocrystalline to amorphous phase transformation for silicon material. Zhang and Tanaka [29] employed MD simulation to study the deformation of silicon in two-body and three-body sliding processes, and confirmed that the dominant phenomenon in this process is amorphous phase. Cheong and Zhang [30] investigated the silicon phase transition under nano-indentation by using MD simulation. It was found that β-silicon with body-centered tetragonal form presents upon loading, and this substance transforms to amorphous phase upon unloading. Also, this process occurs along with loss of long-range order of silicon atoms. Similarly, an investigation of the material deformation behavior in the nano-indentation process was conducted by Lin and Chen [31], in which the investigation of structural phase transformations was conducted on monocrystalline silicon with various orientations. It was discovered that the crystal orientation affects the material hardness, and mixed phases were observed during the loading–unloading process. Han and coworkers [32] applied MD simulation to study the phase transformation in the nanoscratching process. The high hydrostatic pressure is believed to be the reason for breaking up ideal chemical bond interactions, and this in turn drives the transition of classical α-silicon to metallic β-silicon.

Section1.Heading: Model construction
Section1.Para:
In this study, the processes of orthogonal machining using diamond tools are simulated. As indicated in Fig. 1, the silicon work material is a simple block and the diamond tools are constructed in ‘L’ shapes to reduce the atom count and thus the computation time. The cutting tools start to engage the work material and maintain the cutting speed until a pre-determined travel distance is reached. To allow the formation of residual stresses in the material, the cutting tools are then withdrawn and lifted up after making the aforementioned travel distance. In this way, the machined work material goes through relaxation and the stresses remaining inside the material are the residual stresses. All the simulation cases are performed using LAMMPS, a large-scale MD simulation software developed by Sandia National Laboratory [33].
Fig. 1
MD simulation model construction

The cutting tools are treated as rigid bodies in the simulation. The silicon workpiece has a dimension of 432×216×43.2 Å3 (X, Y, and Z directions, respectively). In order to reduce the potential size effects, periodic boundary conditions are applied along the Z direction so that the simulation box is replicated throughout the space to form an infinite lattice. Periodic boundary conditions are usually adopted to mitigate spurious size effects when investigating the behavior of an isolated system. Moreover, in this simulation, the height (Y direction) of the workpiece is much larger than the cutting depth (more than 10 times) to minimize size effects along the Y direction.

Atoms in the silicon workpiece are divided into three regions, namely, fix layer, thermal layer, and Newton block, as shown in the figure. The fix layer acts as a base that fixes the workpiece to be machined. The atoms in the fix layer are fixed, which means that no atom in this layer is subject to any forces acting from other atoms. This avoids the displacement of the workpiece under the engagement of the cutting tool. The thermal layer is located between the Newton block and the fix layer, and it acts as a thermal sink in the machining process. The thermal layer absorbs the heat generation to stabilize the temperature of the entire simulation system. Our investigation of residual stresses is focused on the Newton block. The atoms in the Newton block are subject to severe stress and strain initiated by the movement of the cutting tool.

To understand the effect of machining parameters on residual stresses, a total of six cases are simulated. In this study, we focus on two key machining parameters, namely, depth of cut and tool rake angle. As shown in Table 1, two rake angles (−30∘ and +30∘) and three depths of cut (5 Å, 10 Å, and 15 Å) are considered. The same tool relief angle (30∘), cutting speed (400 m/s), and tool travel distance (250 Å) are used for all the six cases. Note that this kind of cutting speed is very high and rare in realistic operations. High cutting speed is chosen mainly because of the constraints of computation time—each simulation case of 400 m/s cutting speed takes about 5 days to finish by a PC with a 3.2 GHz Intel i7 quad-core processor and 12 GB RAM. Some investigation of the influence of cutting speed in machining operations has been conducted in the literature. It was shown that the variation of cutting speed (100–300 m/min) has an insignificant influence on the cutting force in machining of silicon nitride [34]. Simulation of machining copper with varying cutting speeds from 180 to 720 m/s also confirmed that cutting speed has only a minor influence on cutting force in a steady cutting state [35]. In addition, it is widely accepted that cutting speed increases the hydrostatic stress within the workpiece ahead of the cutting tool, which results in more drastic phase transformation [36, 37]. However, there is a lack of literature reports regarding the tendency of residual stress with cutting speed in the machining of silicon. In terms of machining of steel, no agreement on the relation between cutting speed and residual stress is achieved; some researchers [38, 39] affirmed that surface residual stress increases with cutting speed while a different opinion [40] argued that from a certain cutting speed on, further increase of cutting speed leads to reduction of residual stress.

For all of the six cases, the study of residual stresses is focused on a specific region rather than the entire bulk material. As indicated in Fig. 1, this region is underneath the machined surface, 150 Å away from the edge of the workpiece and has a dimension of 20×80×43.2 Å3. To clearly reveal the distribution of residual stresses along the depth into the surface, this region of interest is evenly divided into 16 layers along the depth (i.e. Y) direction. Thus, each layer has a dimension of 20×5×43.2 Å3 (height, length, and width, respectively). The uppermost layer is aligned with the machined surface of the workpiece. In each layer, the residual stresses are obtained by averaging the stress components of the individual atoms in the layer

The stress status in the work material is dynamical and time dependent during and after machining. After the tool creates the machined surface and then withdraws from the work material, the constraints on the work material need to be removed and the entire work material goes through relaxation for a period of time. The internal stresses become stable and less dynamical, hence the formation of residual stresses. As such, the relatively stable stresses after relaxation are obtained as the residual stresses. To investigate the length of the relaxation process, we obtain a value of 120 ps for all the simulation cases, which turns out to be long enough for the internal stresses in machined surfaces to reach a relatively steady state for our study. To minimize the noise effect of random oscillation of stress, the residual stresses are computed by taking the average of the stress values extracted during the simulation period of 120–180 ps.

The Tersoff potential is applied to model the interaction between the silicon atoms of the work material and the carbon atoms of the diamond tool, as well as the interaction among the silicon atoms. The Tersoff potential is very effective in solving numerically a multi-body problem of mechanics. In 1986, Tersoff first proposed and verified that the Tersoff potential is capable of predicting behaviors of stable phases of diamond cubic silicon and body-centered tetragonal β-silicon [41]. Later in the literature, the Tersoff potential has been widely adopted and verified in predicting mechanical behavior of silicon [42–44]. Based on the concept of bond order, the bond strength is determined by where the electronic charge is sitting in covalent bonding rather than by the coordination of the atoms. The Tersoff potential model for the interactions between atoms can be expressed as follows: 1
$$\begin{aligned} &{E = \sum_{i} E_{i} = \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i \neq j} V_{ij},} \end{aligned}$$
2

3
$$\begin{aligned} &{f_{\mathrm{R}} ( r_{ij} ) = A_{ij} \exp ( - \lambda_{ij} r_{ij} ),} \end{aligned}$$
4

5

Since the Tersoff potential is a three-body potential function that explicitly includes an angular contribution of the force, three elements must be mapped in each entry, which includes all the potential parameters. Thus, an entry for Si–C–C means a Si atom bonded to a C atom with another C atom influencing the bond. In general, the parameters for Si–C–Si and Si–Si–C entries would not be the same. Thus, in this study, eight entries (for Si–Si–Si, Si–Si–C, Si–C–Si, Si–C–C, C–Si–Si, C–Si–C, C–C–Si, C–C–C) must be contained in order to specify all permutations of the two elements interacting in three-body configurations. The summations of interaction forces acting on every tool atom within the cutting tool are obtained as the cutting forces. Certainly, the interaction forces acting on a tool atom are the results of the forces from the neighboring atoms on that specific tool atom. The cutting force can be calculated as 9
$$ F = \sum_{i = 1}^{N_{T}} \sum_{j} f_{ij}, $$ where N

$$ \chi= \frac{1}{\varOmega} \sum_{i}^{N} \biggl(m_{i}v_{i} \otimes v_{i} + \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i \ne j} r_{ij} \otimes f_{ij} \biggr), $$ where Ω stands for the volume of the domain within the cut-off distance of a specific atom, v

$$ S= \sqrt{3 \bigl( S_{xy}^{2} + S_{yz}^{2} + S_{xz}^{2} \bigr) + \frac{1}{ 2} \bigl[ ( S_{xx} - S_{yy} )^{2} + ( S_{xx} - S_{zz} )^{2} + ( S_{zz} - S_{yy} )^{2} \bigr]}. $$

Section2.Heading: Chip formation and cutting forces
Section2.Para:
The machining process of the MD simulation is visualized by the software code of Atomeye [46]. Parts (a) of Figs. 3–8 show the snapshots of the six simulation cases at the tool travel distance of 250 Å. It is found that a similar chip shape can be obtained with the same tool rake angle, and the chip volume is approximately proportional to depth of cut. However, the chip morphologies are very different when the cases with different tool rake angles are compared. In addition, a very obvious ‘bounce-back’ phenomenon below the tool relief face is observed when the −30∘ rake angle is applied (i.e. Cases 1–3). This is because the material is under significant compression due to the large thrust force in machining with negative rake angle tools, and the materials under the tool tip tend to recover right after the tool moves away.

Section2.Heading: Phase transformation
Section2.Para: Single-crystalline silicon is a brittle material in nature. It is confirmed that many brittle materials could exhibit ductile behavior under high hydrostatic pressure. Machining of brittle material in ductile manner was proposed more than two decades ago by Blake and Scattergood [47]. The brittle to ductile transition in silicon is directly related to phase transformation. It is known that high pressure would result in silicon phase transformation from diamond lattice structure to various lattice structures, including amorphous Si, hexagonal phase silicon (Si-IV), and metastable bc8 phase (Si-III); the mixture of these phases finally leads to the amorphization of Si [48]. This amorphous state of silicon is a thin layer with thickness of only a couple of tens to hundreds of nanometers.

To verify the existence of phase transformation of silicon, close-up snapshots of machined silicon surfaces can be examined. Here, only the results of Cases 3 and 6 are shown in Fig. 9. This is because the two cases use the highest amount of depth of cut (15 Å) among all six cases, which generate the most noticeable phase transformation in surfaces for the groups of Cases 1–3 and Cases 4–6, respectively. It can be observed that the silicon atoms in the machined surfaces are no longer arranged regularly, and they rather exhibit random and amorphous patterns. The thicknesses of the amorphous silicon layers are 11.4 Å and 3.2 Å for Cases 3 and 6, respectively. It indicates that when using the same cutting parameters, machining with a negative rake angle produces a deeper layer of amorphous silicon in the machined surface. Certainly, it matches the pattern of cutting forces very well (see Table 3)—higher cutting forces are needed to induce the more severe phase transformation. In addition, the equivalent stress distributions of the two cases are also calculated and shown in Fig. 10. It confirms that high hydrostatic pressure has a deeper penetration when a negative rake angle (Case 3) is used as compared with a positive rake angle (Case 6). Similar observations can be found in the literature for silicon machining at the macrolevel. For instance, Gogotsi and Kirscht [49] discovered that a more negative rake angle is more suitable for ductile cutting of silicon.

Section2.Para:
It is expected that the stress components of surface work materials constantly change as the machining process progresses. The evaluation of stress components in the surface layers is obtained so that the formations of residual stresses are revealed. It is observed that for each of the three stress components σ

xy are similar between the two cases. Recall that the material region of interest is 150 Å from the workpiece edge on the tool entry side (see Fig. 1). This is the distance for the tool to move in for approximately 40 ps, considering that the tool tip is initially placed outside of the workpiece. It can be seen from Fig. 11 that this particular material layer experiences the growth of compressive stresses for all three stress components before the tool reaches the material region of interest. The values of peak compressive stress (σ
xx and σ
yy ) and minimum shear stress (σ
xy ) are observed at around 40 ps, in which they are −14.05 GPa, −18.27 GPa, and −8.36 GPa, respectively. This is because the tool tip is at the position right on top of this material layer, and the dominant compressive stresses are most significant due to the compression effect from the tool. As the tool further progresses, moving away from that material layer, the material experiences a pronounced relaxation, which is reflected by the sharp bounce back towards peak tensile stresses for all three components. In particular, sharp peak tensile stresses of 14.9 GPa and 10.1 GPa can be observed for σ
xx and σ
yy , respectively. The relaxation becomes less drastic, and the stresses start to oscillate within a smaller range after 65 ps, when the tool is withdrawn and the constraints on the workpiece are removed from the interaction with the work material. Eventually, the oscillation fades away. As such, it is reasonable to adopt the average stress values between 120 and 180 ps as the residual stress values.

Figure 12 shows similar stress evolution patterns for the three stress components in Case 4 in which a positive rake angle is applied. Basically, peak compressive stresses of −14.3 GPa, −10.1 GPa, and −9.7 GPa are obtained at around 40 ps, and sharp bounce backs towards tensile residual stresses occur right after the tool moves away from the material layer. Also, the stresses become more stable after the tool is withdrawn and the constraints are removed. The difference is that the stresses are overall more compressive before the arrival of the tool tip than with Case 1, as reflected by either a longer compressive stress duration and/or a higher peak compressive stress value. This is a direct indication that the material undergoes higher drastic hydrostatic pressure when a negative rake angle is applied. The high pressure enables plastic deformation that concentrates in front of the cutting edge, and in turn makes the monocrystalline silicon transform to a more ductile state. After the tool tip leaves the area, the deformed silicon is not able to return to its original structure. As such, the negative rake angle cases (Cases 1–3) tend to machine silicon in a more ductile mode than the corresponding positive rake angle cases (Cases 4–6) under the same configuration of other cutting parameters.

The residual stress distributions along the depth into the machined surface are also computed. Based on the computation results, similar trends are observed among all the cases. For the example of illustration, Fig. 13 shows the results for both Case 1 and Case 4. Two general observations can be made. First, compared with σ
xx , the distributions of σ
yy and σ
xy are much more stable. The volatility of σ
xx is most significant for the first 4–5 material layers, but it decreases to the comparable levels of σ
yy and σ
xy after that. Second, σ
xx always starts from a very high tensile stress value on the machined surface—it is higher than 3 GPa for both cases. It rapidly decreases to the compressive territory beyond the depth of 15 nm into the machined surface. The overall distribution of σ
xx appears to be in a ‘hook’ shape. However, the magnitude of the maximum compressive residual stress is smaller compared to that of the maximum tensile residual stress on the machined surface. In fact, the pattern of in-depth residual stress agrees well with the literature on conventional machining [50–52]. Since the distributions of σ
yy and σ
xy are much less dynamical than that of σ
xx , in the following only σ
xx results are adopted to illustrate the effect of cutting parameters.

Section2.Heading: Effect of cutting parameters on residual stress distributions
Section2.Para:
Figure 14a and b illustrate the effects of depth of cut on residual stress distribution for machining with the −30∘ rake angle tool and the +30∘ rake angle tool, separately. Cases 1–3 employ the same −30∘ rake angle tool, but different levels of depth of cut ranging from 5 Å to 15 Å. It can be seen from Fig. 14a that the residual stresses in the first 3–4 layers are dramatically different among the three cases with the increase of depth of cut. Overall, in those layers, residual stress becomes more compressive as depth of cut increases. For instance, the residual stresses in the first layer are 3.078 GPa, −0.066 GPa, and 1.218 GPa for the depths of cut of 5 Å, 10 Å, and 15 Å, respectively. Meanwhile, all the residual stress curves exhibit a ‘hook’ shape, and the maximum compressive residual stress occurs at about the same depth (75 Å) into the machined surface. Also, the increase of cutting depth tends to increase the maximum compressive residual stress. As depth of cut increases from 5 Å, to 10 Å, and then to 15 Å, correspondingly the maximum compressive residual stress (located at the depth of approximately 15 Å) changes from −1.19 GPa, to −1.65 GPa, and then to −3.75 GPa. In addition, the changes of residual stress are significantly more steady after 25 Å into the surface for all the three cases. However, the effect of depth of cut is less conclusive for the steady portion of the distribution.
Fig. 14
Effect of depth of cut on residual stress distribution for (a) Cases 1–3 with a tool rake angle of −30∘ and (b) Cases 4–6 with a tool rake angle of +30∘

Similar observations can be made when Cases 4–6 are compared in Fig. 14b. The three cases use the same +30∘ rake angle tool, but adopt different depths of cut ranging from 5 Å to 15 Å. The increase of depth of cut tends to produce more compressive residual stress in the first 3–4 layers. Hook-shaped residual stress distributions are obtained for all the cases as well. Also, the residual stress distributions beyond the depth of 20 Å into the surface are relatively steady, and the effect of depth of cut is not monolithic for this portion.

The results indicate that the increase of cutting depth improves the machined surface quality by making the residual stress distributions more compressive. The depths of cut of 0.5 nm, 1 nm and 1.5 nm are less than the silicon’s critical depth of cut for brittle mode machining. It is estimated to be within the range of 20–40 nm, depending on tool rake angle [12]. When the material is machined in ductile regime, the increase of depth of cut introduces higher hydrostatic pressure, and thus a more significant brittle to ductile transition in the vicinity of the tool/work contact area. It leads to a higher compressive stress distribution in the surface layers. Being in ductile mode is critical. Zhang et al. [8] indicated that the residual stress in silicon wafers could be less compressive if the depth of cut is large enough to allow for brittle-mode machining. A similar discovery was also made by other researchers [47, 48].

Figure 15a–c illustrate the effect of tool rake angle on residual stress distribution. Cases 1 and 4 are compared because they have the same machining parameters except for the tool rake angle, and the same reasoning is applied to the comparison groups of Cases 2 and 5, and Cases 3 and 6. It is clear that the use of a −30∘ rake angle tool produces more compressive stress for all the comparison groups. This effect is least significant with the depth of cut of 5 Å, but most significant with the depth of cut of 15 Å. It can be seen from Fig. 15a that at the depth of cut of 5 Å, the residual stress distributions are more compressive in the first 3–4 surface layers when the −30∘ rake angle tool is used, but in the further layers the −30∘ rake angle tool produces less compressive stress as compared with the +30∘ rake angle tool. On the other hand, as shown in Fig. 15c, the residual stress distributions are compressive in the entire depth range when the depth of cut of 15 Å is applied. Also, the negative rake angle produces more compressive residual stresses in the entire depth range compared with the case of positive rake angle. The maximum difference exists at the depth of 25 Å, where Case 3 shows a maximum compressive stress of −3.75 GPa, while Case 6 shows a maximum compressive stress of −1.382 GPa.
Fig. 15
Effect of tool rake angle on residual stress distribution for the case groups of (a) 5 Å depth of cut, (b) 10 Å depth of cut, and (c) 15 Å depth of cut

The effect of rake angle on residual stress distribution for silicon machining can again be attributed to the severity of ductile-mode machining [8, 9]. Negative rake angles introduce more severe ductile deformation and penetration than positive rake angles. Therefore, the relaxation of local strain is more difficult, and the residual stress distribution appears to be more compressive. In addition, it should be noted that the results about rake angle effect are also similar for machining of some metal materials [53, 54], but the mechanisms could be different.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para:
For the first time, the residual stresses produced in nanomachining were investigated by employing the MD simulation approach, while this task remains beyond the reach of any experimental approaches. We not only studied the formation of residual stresses in machined surfaces, but also investigated the effect of certain machining parameters (i.e. depth of cut and tool rake angle) on in-depth residual stress distributions. Based on the results obtained, some major points are summarized as follows.
For silicon machining at the nanometric scale, both depth of cut and tool rake angle affect the chip formation and cutting forces. The overall effects and trends are similar to the observations from conventional machining at the macroscale.
High hydrostatic pressure generated in the vicinity of the tool tip enables phase transformation of silicon material so that it can be machined in ductile mode. However, the depth of phase transformation in the machined surface is shallower than that of residual stress.
The normal residual stress along the cutting direction shows a more dynamical and significant in-depth pattern compared with the other two stress components. Also, for all the simulation cases, this residual stress component starts from tensile and changes to compressive along the depth into the surface. This results in a hook shape for most cases.
The increase of depth of cut tends to reduce the magnitude of maximum tensile residual stress on the surface, and increase the magnitude of compressive residual stress underneath the surface.
Similarly, the use of a positive rake angle makes the residual stress overall more tensile when closer to the surface, and less compressive as the depth into the surface further increases.
